list_definition.definition: to obtain money illegally from (a person), usually by threatening to make known something which the victim wants to keep secret

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The politician was being blackmailed by an ex-girlfriend.
He used blackmail to get money from the senator.

list_ex_of_english: In the first place, factionalised parties made party leaders vulnerable to policy blackmail by powerful factions threatening to switch parties.
First, he claimed that he used the missing file to blackmail the secret police and save his life.
I have urged residents not to give way to blackmail and threats.
However, persuasion was not always enough, and the priests were forced into blackmail.
Unable to sell the worthless cargo, the trio decide to carry out their predecessors' plan to "lose" the ship, then blackmail its owner for the insurance money.
They consolidated their hold over the labourers, maximised their profits and used times of labour shortage to blackmail the planters and to extract exaggerated advances.
The firm is prepared to pay that money, not because of extortion or blackmail but because its unit costs are low.
The group claims that it has been blackmailed.
